comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: St Catherine's Church is now the home of the Core Church, which is in fact still a parish of the Church of Ireland. The parish boundaries at the present time stretch from the Arbour Hill to Christ Church areas....

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: News of the Irish Motor Directory and Motorists' Annual got me excited, but now I see that both photos I have of this old car have no reg number visible. Anyway, it would be great if you could search Dr. Joseph Nolan of Bridge Street, Tullow, County Carlow, my great-grandfather. He's the man behind the wheel in the first photo. The car is a Hupmobile Model 32 which started production in 1912. He died in July 1914, so the picture was taken sometime between 1912 and then. My father has always said that Dr. Nolan owned the first car in County Carlow. Would be nice to know if this is true.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: HUZZAH! We have id-ed these girls. They're Elizabeth or Lily Collins on the left, and her friend Angela Arnold on the right: www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151818708060038&set...

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content:
Barney & Beany  were one of the most successful marketing campaigns EVER run by Batchelors (Ireland), they are originally an British company as far as I know.
The public identified with them straight away with Batchelors  products which is why they have remained in the Public's memory!
Btw, the girls don't look too happy...business particularly quiet??? lol

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The title is a bit anachronistic, as Barney and Beany weren't on Batchelors stuff at the time. If you look at the box, the Batchelors logo of the day can be seen: two identical stick men wearing top hats and carrying canes. On the peas, their heads were green discs, and on beans, a baked-beany orange colour.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Well Done on getting the names of the girls. Fantastic

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] Unfortunately, don't think your great-grandfather's was the very first car! IC 1 to IC 9999 ran from Dec 1903 - Apr 1964. According to the 1907 Irish Motor Directory, IC 1 belonged to Denis Robert Pack-Beresford, Fenagh House, Bagnalstown and IC 2 belonged to the Hon. Rev. Benjamin John Plunkett, Aghade Rectory, Tullow. HOWEVER, the 1912-13 directory shows IC 2 as being registered to Dr. Joseph J. Nolan, Tullow, Co. Carlow! By the 1915-16 directory, IC 2 belongs to Dr. J. B. Keogh, Carrigbyrne, Co. Wexford...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: Brace yerselves for tomorrow's photo, Flickroonies! We're going to venture back into the murky waters of the "unknown" Fergus O'Connor photos, but hopefully it won't be as hard as this one above that billh35 - the BBC call me the "Joker"! (gasp for breath after that mouthful) has never given up on... So far, we've identified 6 out of 7 uploaded. Would ye like to see the really clear one, or the blurry one which ironically has more features that might help you identify where it is?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Re the 3 car photos >> One success, and two failures... According to the Irish Motor Directory and Motorists' Annual for 1915-16, the owner of RI 2987 was Frank D. Mockler, Dunavara, Lucan, so that's brilliant! BUT the London tourists, we think, in LC 2043 aren't featured as there's only Ireland in the Directory. And likewise, the Grafton Street photo is from 1947. IH is in the directory, but only up to IH 278 (the latest directory is 1916).
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: I just wanted to say how much I enjoyed all your photos! I am a Canadian from the west coast with no connection to Ireland (well distant genealogy has some roots) although I can't wait to visit one day! The pictures were amazing and I can't wait to see more! I love how universal some things are no matter the time period or the location.  I also would like to say how much I enjoy all the followers comments and how knowlegable they all are about everything. It has given me a little sunshine on my very rainy BC day!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06]  Have Joined the group, lets see how it goes. But I believe that the [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] show is the best show in town. I come on here every now and then and most times I learn something new, sometimes I laugh like a fool and I am always impressed with the knowledge of the posters and the professionalism and dedication of our esteemed administrator and leader CM. There will be no unfaithfullness from this quarter. :D

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
Danny, I completely agree - and i love seeing what challenges are thrown up - but there are lots of other people who have other places they want located as well - hence the group!

Can you imagine how thrilled I was when I read the BBC website - and all because i made a silly comment on here! I am now hoping that we can get to BBC Breakfast - that's our next target! 

It's also why I have made Carol/NLI a group admin - the NLI role in this is very important and I always think that "historical detective work" is important especially as older people pass away and their knowledge and experience disappears. In Ireland there has always been a tradition of story telling and what goes on here is just the modern version - every picture tells a story. Who would have thought that these two girls could have been identified so quickly!
